snp3.4:0.2.eng: With Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā on the Sacrificial Cake

snp3.4:1.2.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosalesu viharati sundarikāya nadiyā tīre.
snp3.4:1.2.eng: At one time the Buddha was staying in the Kosalan lands on the bank of the Sundarikā river.
snp3.4:1.2.comm: This Sutta is a somewhat altered version of SN 7.9. It contains a range of dense allusions and plays on Vedic concepts.

snp3.4:1.3.pli: Tena kho pana samayena sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo sundarikāya nadiyā tīre aggiṃ juhati, aggihuttaṃ paricarati.
snp3.4:1.3.eng: Now at that time the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā was serving the sacred flame and performing the fire sacrifice on the bank of the Sundarikā.
snp3.4:1.3.comm: This is evidently the midday fire oblation described at Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 2.2.3. A brahmin householder, worshiping when the sun is at its most powerful and the forces of darkness weakest, renders offerings to Agni so that he will drive away evils.

snp3.4:1.4.pli: Atha kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo aggiṃ juhitvā aggihuttaṃ paricaritvā uṭṭhāyāsanā samantā catuddisā anuvilokesi:
snp3.4:1.4.eng: Then he surveyed the four quarters, wondering,

snp3.4:1.5.eng: “Now who might eat the leftovers of this oblation?”

snp3.4:1.6.pli: Addasā kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ avidūre aññatarasmiṃ rukkhamūle sasīsaṃ pārutaṃ nisinnaṃ;
snp3.4:1.6.eng: He saw the Buddha meditating at the root of a certain tree with his robe pulled over his head.

snp3.4:1.7.pli: disvāna vāmena hatthena habyasesaṃ gahetvā dakkhiṇena hatthena kamaṇḍaluṃ gahetvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami.
snp3.4:1.7.eng: Taking the leftovers of the oblation in his left hand and a pitcher in the right he approached the Buddha.

snp3.4:2.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sundarikabhāradvājassa brāhmaṇassa padasaddena sīsaṃ vivari.
snp3.4:2.1.eng: When he heard Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā’s footsteps the Buddha uncovered his head.

snp3.4:2.2.pli: Atha kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo: “muṇḍo ayaṃ bhavaṃ, muṇḍako ayaṃ bhavan”ti tatova puna nivattitukāmo ahosi.
snp3.4:2.2.eng: Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā thought, “This man is shaven, he is shaven!” And he wanted to turn back.

snp3.4:2.4.pli: “muṇḍāpi hi idhekacce brāhmaṇā bhavanti, yannūnāhaṃ upasaṅkamitvā jātiṃ puccheyyan”ti.
snp3.4:2.4.eng: “Even some brahmins are shaven. Why don’t I go to him and ask about his birth?”

snp3.4:2.5.pli: Atha kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.4:2.5.eng: Then the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā went up to the Buddha, and said to him,

snp3.4:3.1.pli: Atha kho bhagavā sundarikabhāradvājaṃ brāhmaṇaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
snp3.4:3.1.eng: Then the Buddha addressed Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā in verse:

snp3.4:4.1.eng: “I am no brahmin, nor am I a ruler,
snp3.4:4.1.comm: Here rājaputta is a synonym of khattiya.

snp3.4:4.3.eng: Fully understanding the clan of ordinary people,

snp3.4:4.4.eng: I wander in the world owning nothing, reflective.

snp3.4:5.1.eng: Clad in my cloak, I wander without home,

snp3.4:5.3.eng: Since I’m unburdened by the sons of Manu,
snp3.4:5.3.comm: Māṇava, which normally means “Vedic student”, is occasionally used in the poetic sense of manussa (“humans”). Both words mean “descendant of the first man, Manu”. The Buddha, it would seem, is playing on the two senses. Normally, having Vedic students is an honor for a teacher, but here the Buddha celebrates his freedom.

snp3.4:5.4.eng: it’s inappropriate to ask me about clan.”

snp3.4:6.1.eng: “Actually sir, when brahmins meet they politely

snp3.4:6.2.eng: ask each other whether they are brahmins.”

snp3.4:7.1.eng: “Well, if you say that you’re a brahmin,

snp3.4:7.3.eng: I shall question you on that Sāvitrī Prayer,
snp3.4:7.3.comm: The Buddha is demonstrating his expertise. The verse here called Sāvittī (Sanskrit Sāvitrī) may be recited in Gāyatrī or (with an introductory line added) Anuṣṭubh metres. The form specified here is the Gāyatrī, which is the form recommended for the initiation of a student in the Śukla Yajurveda tradition, reflecting the lineage practiced by Siddhattha under his former teachers (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 11.5.4.13, Bṛhadāraṇyaka Upaniṣad 5.14). This verse is also mentioned at Snp 3.7:35.2 = MN 92:26.2 = Kd 6:35.8.3.

snp3.4:7.4.eng: with its three lines and twenty-four syllables.”
snp3.4:7.4.comm: The commentary re-interprets this to mean the famous formula of going for refuge, which is not metrical, but like the Sāvitrī has three lines of eight syllables.

snp3.4:8.1.eng: “On what grounds have seers and men,

snp3.4:8.2.eng: aristocrats and brahmins here in the world

snp3.4:8.3.eng: performed so many different sacrifices to the gods?”

snp3.4:9.1.eng: “During a sacrifice, should a past-master, <j>a knowledge master,

snp3.4:9.2.eng: receive an oblation, it profits the donor, I say.”

snp3.4:10.1.eng: “Then clearly my oblation will be profitable,”

snp3.4:10.3.eng: “since I have met such a knowledge master.

snp3.4:10.4.eng: It’s because I’d never met anyone like you

snp3.4:10.5.eng: that others ate the sacrificial cake.”
snp3.4:10.5.comm: The pūraḷāsa (Sanskrit puroḍāśa) is the “fore-offering”, which originally might be the goat that is led before the horse to the sacrifice (Rig Veda 1.162.3). The reference here, however, is to the cakes of rice-meal steeped in ghee that are offered to Agni (Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 2.2.3.14).

snp3.4:11.1.eng: “So then, brahmin, since you have approached me

snp3.4:11.2.eng: as a seeker of the good, ask.
snp3.4:11.2.comm: Norman and Bodhi both have “approach and ask”, but upasaṅkamma is absolutive: he is already there.

snp3.4:11.3.eng: Perhaps you may find here someone intelligent,

snp3.4:11.4.eng: peaceful, unclouded, untroubled, <j>with no need for hope.”

snp3.4:12.2.eng: and wish to perform a sacrifice. Please advise me,

snp3.4:12.4.pli: Yattha hutaṃ ijjhate brūhi me taṃ”.
snp3.4:12.4.eng: where an oblation is profitable; tell me this.”

snp3.4:13.1.pli: “Tena hi tvaṃ, brāhmaṇa, odahassu sotaṃ; dhammaṃ te desessāmi—
snp3.4:13.1.eng: “Well then, brahmin, listen up, I will teach you the Dhamma.

snp3.4:14.1.eng: Don’t ask about birth, ask about conduct;

snp3.4:14.2.eng: for the fire of Jātaveda is born from sticks.
snp3.4:14.2.comm: The line plays with jāti (“birth”), jāyati (“give birth”), and jātaveda. The latter term is a Vedic word for fire. Its meaning is obscure, but I think the sense is jāta (“those who have been born”, i.e. “mortals”) plus vedas (“knowledge”), i.e. “one who brings knowledge to mortals”. This is the fire-god Agni, who comes down from the sun to the sacrificial fire, bringing light and awareness and Vedic knowledge to those who have been born, namely mortal humans. In this passage, it implies that anyone who “has been born” can “give birth” to “knowledge” regardless of their “birth”.

snp3.4:14.3.eng: A steadfast sage, even though from a low class family,

snp3.4:14.4.eng: is a thoroughbred checked by conscience.

snp3.4:15.1.eng: Tamed by truth, fulfilled by taming,

snp3.4:15.2.eng: a complete knowledge master <j>who has completed the spiritual journey—

snp3.4:15.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.4:15.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.4:16.1.eng: Those who have left sensuality behind, <j>wandering homeless,

snp3.4:16.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.4:16.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.4:17.1.eng: Those freed of greed, with senses stilled,

snp3.4:17.2.eng: like the moon released from the eclipse—

snp3.4:17.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.4:17.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.4:18.2.eng: always mindful, calling nothing their own—

snp3.4:18.3.eng: that is where a brahmin seeking merit

snp3.4:18.4.eng: should bestow a timely oblation as sacrifice.

snp3.4:19.2.eng: knowing the end of rebirth and death,

snp3.4:19.3.eng: quenched and cool as a lake:

snp3.4:19.4.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

snp3.4:20.1.eng: Good among the good, far from the bad,

snp3.4:20.2.eng: the Realized One has infinite wisdom.

snp3.4:20.3.eng: Unsullied in this life and the next:

snp3.4:20.4.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

snp3.4:21.1.pli: Yamhi na māyā vasati na māno,
snp3.4:21.1.eng: In whom dwells no deceit or conceit,

snp3.4:21.2.eng: rid of greed, unselfish, with no need for hope,

snp3.4:21.4.eng: a brahmin rid of sorrow’s stain:

snp3.4:21.5.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

snp3.4:22.1.eng: He has given up the mind’s home,

snp3.4:22.2.eng: and has no possessions at all.

snp3.4:22.3.eng: Not grasping to this life or the next:

snp3.4:22.4.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

snp3.4:23.1.eng: Serene, he has crossed the flood,

snp3.4:23.2.eng: and has understood the teaching with ultimate view.

snp3.4:23.3.eng: With defilements ended, bearing his final body:

snp3.4:23.4.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

snp3.4:24.1.eng: In whom desire to be reborn, and caustic speech

snp3.4:24.2.eng: are cleared and ended, they are no more;

snp3.4:24.4.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

snp3.4:25.1.eng: He has slipped his chains, he’s chained no more,

snp3.4:25.2.eng: among those caught in conceit he is free of conceit;

snp3.4:25.3.eng: he has fully understood suffering <j>with its field and ground:

snp3.4:25.4.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

snp3.4:26.1.eng: Not relying on hope, seeing seclusion,

snp3.4:26.2.eng: well past the views proclaimed by others.

snp3.4:26.3.eng: In him there are no supporting conditions at all:

snp3.4:26.4.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

snp3.4:27.1.eng: He has comprehended all things, high and low,

snp3.4:27.2.eng: cleared them and ended them, so they are no more.

snp3.4:27.3.eng: Peaceful, freed in the ending of grasping:

snp3.4:27.4.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

snp3.4:28.1.eng: He sees the ending of rebirth’s fetter,

snp3.4:28.2.eng: and has cast aside all manner of desire.

snp3.4:28.4.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

snp3.4:29.1.eng: Not seeing himself in terms of a self,

snp3.4:29.2.eng: he is stilled, sincere, and steadfast.

snp3.4:29.4.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.

snp3.4:30.1.eng: He harbors no delusions within at all,

snp3.4:30.2.eng: he has insight into all things.

snp3.4:30.4.eng: attained to the state of grace, the supreme awakening.

snp3.4:30.5.eng: That’s how the purity of a spirit is defined:
snp3.4:30.5.comm: Here the Buddha refers to himself as a yakkha.

snp3.4:30.6.eng: the Realized One is worthy of the sacrificial cake.”

snp3.4:31.1.eng: “Let my oblation be a true offering,

snp3.4:31.2.eng: since I have found such a knowledge master!

snp3.4:31.3.pli: Brahmā hi sakkhi paṭigaṇhātu me bhagavā,
snp3.4:31.3.eng: I see divinity in person! <j>Accept my offering, Blessed One:

snp3.4:32.1.eng: “Food enchanted by a verse isn’t fit for me to eat.
snp3.4:32.1.comm: Śatapatha Brāhmaṇa 2.2.3.14 says the verses to be recited are those of five-syllable lines, because there are five potsherds on which the rice-cakes are offered, and five seasons in which Agni abides. These verses are from Rig Veda 4.10 in praise of Agni, who expels the “baggage” of sinful deeds.

snp3.4:32.2.eng: That’s not the principle of those who see, brahmin.

snp3.4:32.3.eng: The Buddhas cast aside things enchanted with verses.

snp3.4:32.4.eng: Since there is such a principle, brahmin, <j>that’s how they live.

snp3.4:33.1.eng: Serve with other food and drink

snp3.4:33.2.eng: the consummate one, the great seer,

snp3.4:33.3.eng: with defilements ended and remorse stilled.

snp3.4:33.4.eng: For he is the field for the seeker of merit.”

snp3.4:34.2.eng: now that I have found your teaching,

snp3.4:34.3.eng: when I look for someone during a sacrifice,

snp3.4:34.4.eng: who should eat the <j>religious donation of one like me?”

snp3.4:35.1.comm: This does not seem entirely coherent, as the Buddha just rejected such food, although it is perhaps not a direct contradiction. But compare SN 7.9:9.2, where the Buddha says enchanted food should be discarded.

snp3.4:35.3.eng: who is liberated from sensual pleasures,

snp3.4:35.4.eng: and who has cast aside dullness.

snp3.4:36.1.eng: One who has erased perimeters and limits,

snp3.4:36.4.eng: When such a person comes to the sacrifice,

snp3.4:37.3.eng: and venerate them with food and drink,

snp3.4:37.4.eng: and in this way your religious donation will succeed.”

snp3.4:38.1.eng: “The Buddha is worthy of the sacrificial cake,

snp3.4:38.2.eng: he is the supreme field of merit,

snp3.4:38.3.eng: Recipient of gifts from the whole world,

snp3.4:38.4.eng: what’s given to the worthy one is very fruitful.”

snp3.4:39.1.pli: Atha kho sundarikabhāradvājo brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
snp3.4:39.1.eng: Then the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā said to the Buddha,

snp3.4:39.3.pli: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṃ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṃ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa vā maggaṃ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṃ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti; evamevaṃ bhotā gotamena anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
snp3.4:39.3.eng: As if he were righting the overturned, or revealing the hidden, or pointing out the path to the lost, or lighting a lamp in the dark so people with clear eyes can see what’s there, worthy Gotama has made the teaching clear in many ways.

snp3.4:39.4.pli: Esāhaṃ bhavantaṃ gotamaṃ saraṇaṃ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.
snp3.4:39.4.eng: I go for refuge to the worthy Gotama, to the teaching, and to the mendicant Saṅgha.

snp3.4:39.5.pli: Labheyyāhaṃ bhoto gotamassa santike pabbajjaṃ, labheyyaṃ upasampadan”ti.
snp3.4:39.5.eng: May I receive the going forth, the ordination in the worthy Gotama’s presence?”

snp3.4:39.6.eng: And the brahmin Bhāradvāja of Sundarikā received the going forth, the ordination in the Buddha’s presence.

snp3.4:39.7.eng: And soon after, he became one of the perfected.
